...and do taste the salt—it should be slightly strong. If the water is salty, the biryani rice will be well balanced. Also, add a little salt to the korma. No matter how many spices you use, if there’s not enough salt, it won’t taste right. The true test of good food is balanced salt.
The water has now come to a boil. Let’s uncover it. Basmati rice needs quick handling—don't take too much time with it.

After boiling, cook the rice for 5–6 minutes. That’s enough. Cook them only 50–60%. The rice has expanded in length. Now I’ll remove about half of them. These partially cooked rice (60%) will be layered into the korma. It’s simple—don’t overthink it.
I know my home-cook sisters and mothers may not understand terms like “1 string” or “2 string” stages—that’s more for commercial or professional chefs.

So just remember this simple rule: After boiling starts, give it 4–5 boils, then remove slightly more than half the rice and put it into the korma. Increase the flame now. The remaining 30–40% of the rice will be cooked for another minute, and reserve 1–2 cups of the starchy water—we’ll need that.
Now I’ve increased the flame under the pot. Whenever you add the second layer of rice, turn up the heat. Don’t spread the rice with a steel spoon—use a cloth or a napkin to settle the rice.

transcript_segments.text: Finally, I’m adding a cup of the oil used for frying onions on top. This gives shine and prevents the rice from sticking. Remember: biryani needs oil to taste good. You can’t diet and expect restaurant-style biryani. Either choose diet food or make real biryani.
